The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept

Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included

Relates a concept to the concept scheme that it is a top level concept of

A metamorphic facies is defined by a repeatedly occurring and thus predictable set of stable mineral assemblages in metamorphic rocks. Such metamorphic mineral assemblages crystallize and are stable over a range of externally imposed physical conditions, most crucially lithostatic pressure and temperature, and thus the facies define areas in two-dimensional plots of pressure–temperature space. There is a demonstrable/proven relationship between mineral composition and bulk rock chemical composition and a consistent relationship through geological time. Rocks which contain certain metamorphic mineral assemblages can therefore be linked to particular tectonic settings, times and places in the geological history of an area. The boundaries between facies are typically gradational as the disappearance or appearance of minerals occurs over pressure, temperature, space and time. The vocabulary is based on Fettes and Desmons (2007, Metamorphic Rocks: a classification and glossary of terms — Recommendations of the International Union of Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Metamorphic Rocks edited by D Fettes and J Desmons, 244p.), with further subdivisions for some facies. Definitions also borrow from Neuendorf et al. (2005, Glossary of Geology: 5th edition, revised edited by KKE Neuendorf, JP Mehl Jr and JA Jackson: American Geological Institute, Alexandria, Virginia, USA, 779p.). More detailed metamorphic mineral assemblages for specific rock types can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_facies).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Metamorphic facies representing the highest grades of metamorphism; it forms at high temperature and at medium and high pressure/temperature values and lies between the eclogite and pyroxene-hornfels facies. It is characterized by clinopyroxene (diopside) – orthopyroxene (hypersthene) – plagioclase assemblages with minor and usually Ti-rich amphibole in rocks of basaltic composition. Almandine-rich garnet is characteristic of metabasic and metapelitic rocks. Metapelitic mineral assemblages show the association of sillimanite or kyanite with perthitic feldspar and garnet at higher pressures, and cordierite and orthopyroxene at lower pressures; muscovite is absent and biotite abundance is low. At the highest temperatures, diagnostic minerals are sapphirine and osumilite in Mg-rich metasiliciclastic rocks. The presence of leucosomes due to in situ partial melting is common. The facies occurs at higher temperature than the amphibolite facies. The facies is typical of regional or high-temperature contact metamorphism at pressures of about 2–17kbar in excess of about 700–750°C. The facies encompasses moderate to high (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow typical of many tectonic environments, and it is thus a common metamorphic facies for metamorphosed rocks.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definitions adapted from IUGS (2007); Glossary of Geology (5th edition, American Geosciences Institute); Harley (1998; On the occurrence and characterization of ultrahigh-temperature crustal metamorphism, in What drives metamorphism and metamorphic relations? edited by PJ Treloar and PJ O'Brien: The Geological Society of London, Special Publication138,p.81–107); and Vernon and Clarke (2008; Principles of metamorphic petrology / Cambridge University Press. ISBN: 9780521871785. xi, 446p).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Metamorphic facies representing the highest grades of metamorphism; it forms at high temperature and at medium and high pressure/temperature values and lies between the eclogite and pyroxene-hornfels facies. It is characterized by clinopyroxene (diopside) – orthopyroxene (hypersthene) – plagioclase assemblages with minor and usually Ti-rich amphibole in rocks of basaltic composition. Almandine-rich garnet is characteristic of metabasic and metapelitic rocks. Metapelitic mineral assemblages show the association of sillimanite or kyanite with perthitic feldspar and garnet at higher pressures, and cordierite and orthopyroxene at lower pressures; muscovite is absent and biotite abundance is low. At the highest temperatures, diagnostic minerals are sapphirine and osumilite in Mg-rich metasiliciclastic rocks. The presence of leucosomes due to in situ partial melting is common. The facies occurs at higher temperature than the amphibolite facies. The facies is typical of regional or high-temperature contact metamorphism at pressures of about 2–17kbar in excess of about 700–750°C. The facies encompasses moderate to high (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow typical of many tectonic environments, and it is thus a common metamorphic facies for metamorphosed rocks.

High-pressure subset of the granulite facies, reserved for rocks within the kyanite stability field, but below pressures corresponding to the stability of jadeite–quartz of the eclogite facies. It is typical of high-grade regional metamorphism of deep crust under moderate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions. The highest temperature high-pressure granulite facies rocks probably require rocks to be pre-conditioned (refractory) in order for such thermal conditions to be attained.
A profile for SKOS Concept Schemes
